none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from F. Van Winkle, July 20, 1883
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from F. Van Winkle, July 20, 1883
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 14 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
22 Cortlandt St - N.Y
July 20 - 1883 -

Friend Mc Innis -

As per head you
will understand that
I am settled in new
quarters - I have been some-
what delayed on account of
sickness of my brother Al_
He is laid up in con-
equence of lodgment of
black berry seeds - causing
very painful and dangrous
illness. We have
hopes of his recovry thugh
though last Tuesday we
were fearful for his life.
I found all in good health
and with exception of J.A.

**Detailed Transcription Analysis and Refinement** Okay, here's my breakdown of this letter transcription. The user has provided an image of a handwritten letter, and I'm tasked with creating a faithful transcription. I've begun by analyzing the image, noting the date, location (22 Cortlandt St - N.Y., July 20, 1883), and salutation ("Friend Mc Innis -"). The letter appears to discuss the writer's new living situation and his brother's illness, caused by consuming blackberry seeds, a "very painful and dangrous illness." There's some concern about his brother's recovery. I've gone through the handwriting meticulously, line by line, identifying each word and paying close attention to any ambiguities or potential misspellings. My initial transcription: ```html

22 Cortlandt St - N.Y
July 20 - 1883 -

Friend Mc Innis -

As per head you
will understand that
I am settled in new
quarters - I have been some-
what delayed on account of
sickness of my brother Al_
He is laid up in con-
equence of lodgment of
black berry seeds - causing
very painful and dangrous
illness. We have
hopes of his recovry thugh
though last Tuesday we
were fearful for his life.
I found all in good health
and with exception of J.A.

``` I have focused on preserving the writer's intent and any peculiarities in the handwriting. I’m interpreting the handwriting as precisely as possible. My notes and refinements below demonstrate a thorough analytical approach: * **Header and Salutation**: I've transcribed "22 Cortlandt St - N.Y / July 20 - 1883 -" and "Friend Mc Innis -." I've represented the "Mc" using `Mc` to reflect the small, superscript 'c' in the original. * **Body Text**: I've transcribed the rest of the letter, with line breaks and hyphens. * **Ambiguities:** * **"con- / equence"**: This was the most challenging part. The handwriting appears to show "cn- equence," but the intended word is undoubtedly "consequence." I've chosen to transcribe "con-" and "equence" to reflect the actual letters visible. * **"dangrous"**: The handwriting is not fully clear for "dangerous" at the end. I’ve transcribed "dangrous" to match the visual evidence. * **"recovry"**: Looks like it is "recovry" without the "e". * **"thugh / though"**: The word "though" is repeated on a line break, and one looks like "thugh", so I have made both transcriptions, representing each letter. * **"Al\_"**: It could be "Al." with a long dash at the end, I have chosen to use `Al_` as that's what the writing looks like. I've made sure to adhere to the given constraints, focusing on accuracy, and only using permitted HTML tags. I have tried to be literal, yet readable, when making my decisions. I believe this transcription accurately represents the letter's content and the writer's handwriting, while remaining within the specified guidelines.

[Header] 2 they have remained so - I had pleasantest journey of any I have ever taken! Perhaps had as pleasant prospects as ^on any previous one. Came straight through. Got lost in Cincinnatti with a fellow and barely caught the train. Was delayed 12 hours in Northern N.Y, by the party passengers in our ^party sleeper made up picnic party and "target excursion" us- ing my rifle &c. Made acquaintance of some nice femmes on cars from St. L., they live in Brooklyn Found my fathers health very much improved - the girls are blooming as ever - Lowie has gone

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Letter (Page 2)**

Alright, here’s how I’m approaching this. The task is to get a readable transcription from an image of a handwritten letter, and I need to think this through carefully, line by line. It's on lined paper, in cursive, and it looks like a somewhat rushed script but generally clear. There's a page number "2" which tells me it's continuing from somewhere.

I'm starting at the top:

1.  Header: Page number "2"
2.  "they have remained so -" This looks like the end of something from the previous page.
3.  "I had pleasantest journey" – The "I" looks slightly off, but the context points towards "I," and it's followed by a clear, capital "I." But wait, it looks like "They" is crossed out. So it's "They have remained so - I had..." got it.
4.  "of any I have ever taken!" – Straightforward.
5.  "Perhaps had as pleasant" – No problem here.
6.  "prospects as ^on any previous one." – Insertion marker and "on" added.
7.  "Came straight through. Got" – Easy.
8.  "lost in Cincinnati with" – Cincinnati is interesting, spelled a bit oddly ("Cincinnatti"). Double "t" perhaps.
9.  "a fellow and barely caught" – No problems.
10. "the train. Was delayed" – Good.
11. "12 hours in Northern N.Y," – All clear.
12. "by the freight passengers" (Here we go...) – This is where things get tricky. The handwriting is a little unclear on this word. The letter is starts with 'f' or 'p'. The next word is "passengers". The most likely option in context is "freight passengers". But let's check it. "freight" "f-r-e-i-g-h-t?" or "f-o-r-t-y"? And the "t" at the end looks like a tail. "freighty"? No. But it could be a 'g' loop that didn't close. The context... a train delay. Freight makes more sense than "forty" or "party". But, let's keep going.
    -   Let's check the line below: "in our party sleeper". Aha, the word "party" is *very* clear there.
    -   And there is a caret, indicating the writer thought about "party." Maybe the first word is *party?* But the first letter looks like 'f'. But the 'p' in pleasantest. It matches the shape. "Was delayed 12 hours... by the party passengers? It seems weird. But in context of a sleeper and picnic, it does fit. Let's dig in.
    - The delay makes sense if caused by freight, less sense for a party. I'll read freight. But it ends in y loop and "passengers" is a long word. I'm going with "party."
    - Maybe "forty passengers"?
    - Let's read "freight". The word ends in y. It should end in t.
13. "in our ^party sleeper" - So, "party" is inserted into the previous line, with a caret above it. It could mean the author wrote freight initially and then inserted party. The first letter, I think is a sloppy 'p'. So "party"? So the first word in line 12 is "party". And there is more context for "party":
14. "made up picnic party" – The word "party" is here and it's clear. Then there is an "and 'target excursion' us-".
    - "ing my rifle &c. Made" is fine and a good sentence.
15. "acquaintance of some nice" – Good.
16. "femmes on cars from St. L.," - The word is "femmes", is it friends? No, femmes are women. Strange word, but it makes sense here.
17. "they live in Brooklyn" - All good. Let's put a paragraph break here and see what the next paragraph is.
18. "Found my fathers health" - Okay, new paragraph.
19. "very much improved - the" - Great.
20. "girls are blooming as" - Yes.
21. "ever - Lowie has gone" - Perfect.

Alright, a few final checks. Is it "Northern N.Y" or "N.H"? It looks like N.

3 Try to liv - with father -
Have met many old
friends here and made
many new ones - will
live in Paterson for some
time to come. Have a
good location pleasant
neighbors and very fair
prospects. Feel more san-
guine of good business pros-
pects than did before getting
on ground - My specialty
is mill work and Machine
supplies - I have seen
nothing in paper - "Galvn News"
of meeting of Bd of Directors
Please inform Judg Thomas
that Mr. Sheldon recently
came to N. Y to live.
I have written to
another party - Whitlock -
a graduate of Stevens

**Document Decryption: A Step-by-Step Analysis**

Alright, let's break this down. First, this looks like a page from a handwritten letter, marked as "3" in the top left corner – a key indicator for determining its place in the overall document. The script is cursive, and while generally readable, it definitely has some idiosyncratic letter forms that need careful scrutiny. The dark ink on lined paper gives me a good visual contrast to work with.

Starting from the top, the first line is always the trickiest. "3 Try to liv - with father -" or "3 Try to live- with father -". Hmmm, the first word is the one that is giving me the trouble. My first thought is "Try." It starts with an elongated cursive "T," and is the best fit in the context of the sentence as an imperative. The next bit is "liv" or "live." The loop at the end seems to indicate the letter "e," but the last stroke is incomplete. So, I will write it as "liv" in the transcript.

The following lines flow pretty smoothly: "Have met many old friends here and made many new ones - will live in Paterson for some time to come..." The writer is describing their current living situation, a new location in Paterson, and making friends. "Have a good location pleasant neighbors and very fair prospects." Sounds promising.

Digging further, I come across a line about feeling "more sanguine of good business prospects than did before getting on ground". I have a specialty. Okay, so I am going to try and get to the bottom of the last word. The handwriting is a bit more stylized here, but it looks like "specialty" is written correctly in this context. It's legible but has a bit of a loop so, I will be careful. My area of expertise seems to be related to "mill work and Machine supplies..." It's starting to make sense, a business. The writer is mentioning something they saw "nothing in paper - "Galvn News"". Hmmm. The word "Galvn" catches my eye. It looks like it could be short for "Galveston" or a similar place. I will also make a note for a more thorough investigation.

The next lines discuss a meeting of the "Bd of Directors" (I'll note "Bd" is short for "Board"). The writer also mentions informing "Judg Thomas" (definitely "Judge"). After that is the reference of the arrival of "Mr. Sheldon" to "N. Y" to live – which has to mean New York.

Finally, I have a few more pieces to transcribe. The writer has written to someone named "Whitlock," who is a "graduate of Stevens." Based on the "Machine supplies" and the reference to Paterson/NYC, "Stevens" (Institute of Technology) seems like a very plausible candidate.

So, let's revisit that "Galvn News" bit. The G is clear. a-l-v-n. Is it an abbreviation? Or is it “Galvn”? Or is there another similar-sounding publication? I'm going to take a closer look at that, maybe cross-reference it with any historical publications from around that period in the NYC area. It has to be accurate. The writing seems clear and the writer appears to have an occupation.

"Liv"? Well, let's keep it "liv" unless there is another way to make sense of the word.

At a second look, the word "specialty". It looks like an "especially" but I'm going to lean towards "specialty". A good engineer. A good writer.

"Stevens". Yes. Looks clear.

The work is done. Time to transcribe.

now in employment of
Brooks Loco Works, Dun-
kirk - He is in
charge of a Technical
school - under auspices

Whitlock is the only avail-

**Detailed Thought Process for Transcribing the Handwritten Document**

Okay, here's the deal. I've been given an image of a handwritten document and my task is to produce an accurate transcription, while adhering to specific guidelines.  Let's break this down.

First, I looked at the image, taking in the basic visual information: it's a page of handwritten text, likely a letter, written in dark ink on lined paper. The handwriting is cursive – flowing, but legible enough. There are a few cross-outs, which will need careful consideration.

Now, line-by-line transcription. I'm going through each word, trying to capture it exactly. Some words are clear; others are trickier.

*   **Line 1:** "now in employment of" – Straightforward.
*   **Line 2:** "Brooks Loco Works, Dun-" – "Loco Works" is clear, and the context suggests "Dunkirk", which fits the information.
*   **Line 3:** "kirk - He is \[crossed out: the] in" – Here's the first tricky part. There's a word crossed out. The instructions are to be accurate. The crossed-out word is "the". I can't use a strikethrough tag, so I'm going to omit it to maintain readability, but I'll make a mental note.
*   **Line 4:** "charge of a Technical" - No problems
*   **Line 5:** "school - under auspices" - No problems
*   **Line 6:** "of Mr. Brooks - in Dunkirk." - No problems
*   **Line 7:** "Whitlock is the only avail-" - A name. Looks clear enough.
*   **Line 8:** "able and suitable person" - No problems
*   **Line 9:** "I can get track of for" - "track" is a bit ambiguous, but fits context.
*   **Line 10:** "my successor. Stevens grad-" - "Stevens" needs verification based on context ("Technical school"), and this is likely to be "Stevens Institute of Technology". The "grad-" is straightforward.
*   **Line 11:** "uates are very cautious" - No problems
*   **Line 12:** "about recommendations for" - No problems
*   **Line 13:** "such a position and W, is" - "W" likely refers to Whitlock.
*   **Line 14:** "the only one generally en-" - Context is beginning to guide the transcription
*   **Line 15:** "dorsed - I do not re-" - Now, the real challenge. The word "dorsed" is the problem. The letter is tricky! It *looks* like "censed" or "ersed", but it has to be "endorsed". I'm relying on context and the overall logic of the sentence. The hyphen also helps confirm this word. I'm going to spend a while looking closely at the characters in the word: `d` `o` `r` `s` `e` `d`. It has to be "endorsed," even though the "d" is a bit squashed.
*   **Line 16:** "member him - as he was" - "member" is pretty clear, but double-checking is smart. The "as" could look like "es", but given context, it's clearly "as".
*   **Line 17:** "about 3 years behind me -" - No problem
*   **Line 18:** "I have written him in -" - No Problem
*   **Line 19:** "viting him to come and see" - "viting" and "see" are easy. "come" looks okay, cursive m's can be tricky.

Now, for any specific tricky parts or ambiguity, I'm going to re-check the troublesome areas:

*   **"Dun-"** (Line 2) becomes "Dunkirk". The context confirms this (Brooks Locomotive Works was in Dunkirk).
*   **"He is \[crossed out: the] in"** (Line 3): The "the" is crossed out. The challenge: represent the deletion accurately. Since I can't use a strikethrough, I'll omit to keep the transcription as readable as possible.
*   **"Whitlock"** (Line 7): Clearly a name. No issue.
*   **"track"** (Line 9): Could be "touch," but "track of" (meaning to find) fits the context.
*   **"Stevens"** (Line 10): Confirmed, referencing "Technical

[Header]

[1883, July 20]

me.
     I will take about
2 3 weeks vacation and then
"pitch in" in good earnest.
What is to be done in re-
gard to building extensions?
I would make plans
and specifications for present-
ation to building committee
also complete specification
of shop or other improvements
provided they would be
accepted by Board.
Who could I employ to
look after such business
for me - i.e. present to
Bd for approval and be
protected from theft -
It must be that they are

desirous of having plans,
for elevations and spec-
ifications for buildings as
soon as possible.

Any practical builder could
see that specifications are
carried out and report to
building committee or
business manager –
I have not as yet rec'd
my boxes or heard any
thing from them.

Please remember me to
the faculty and famalies.
Let me hear from
you at earliest
convenience –

Yours truly
Franklin Van Winkle

P.S. Do you think you
could look after that
business for me –
F.V.W.
